title: AB 933
content: The State of California enacts the following. The Legislature enacted the 24/7 Sobriety program in California to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and NHTSA funding. Section 23582.5 of the Vehicle Code allows the court to order individuals convicted of DUI offenses to participate in a qualified 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of probation, parole, or sentence if certain criteria are met. The court may require a person arrested for DUI to enroll in a qualified 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of release on bond if certain criteria are met. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program to obtain a restricted driving privilege if they committed a violation within 10 years of a previous DUI conviction. Participation in the program is required for a minimum of one year. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program for a minimum of one year. The program requires abstaining from alcohol or controlled substances, undergoing breath testing at least twice daily, and facing immediate sanctions for violations. The methodology must be evidence-based. Evaluation research confirms that the 24/7 Sobriety program produces positive results attributed to the program itself, peer-reviewed by experts, and endorsed by federal agencies. Participants may also be required to engage in other DUI programs as mandated by California law. Testing methods for violations should be timely and effective. The court shall impose a program of no more than 180 days unless the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs or fails to appear for a test. Participants must pay program costs based on their ability to pay. Testing methods for violations should be timely and effective. The court may impose a program up to 180 days if the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs or misses a test. The Office of Traffic Safety must include provisions for the 24/7 Sobriety program in its highway safety plan. The department will collect data on participant demographics, case history, testing information, and fees. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code allows for public inspection of department records related to vehicle registration, driver's license applications, convictions, and accident reports, except in cases where confidentiality is required by law. Abstracts of accident reports are available to law enforcement and courts. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on specific time limits: 10 years for certain violations, 7 years for violations with two points, and 3 years for accidents and other violations. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports based on specific time limits: 10 years for certain violations, 7 years for violations with two points, and 3 years for accidents and all other violations. Suspensions and revocations of driving privileges are disclosed while in effect and for three years after termination, except for specific cases. Judicially set aside or stayed suspensions or revocations are not disclosed. The department in Sacramento discloses convictions and accident reports within specific time limits. Suspensions and revocations are disclosed while in effect and for three years after termination, except for cases that are judicially set aside or stayed. Personal information is only disclosed in compliance with the Driver’s Privacy Protection Act of 1994. Penalties for specific convictions are disclosed to courts and law enforcement agencies for 10 years from the date of the offense. The department in Sacramento discloses convictions and accident reports within specific time limits, including penalties for certain offenses. Consent for the use of a driver's license number by insurance agents or employers is presumed if provided for insurance coverage or employment eligibility. The insurance agent or broker is authorized to transmit motor vehicle records for specific purposes. They are not responsible for the handling of the records by authorized recipients. Prior to transmitting records, the broker or agent must obtain a written agreement from the insurer or third party to handle the records in accordance with state and federal laws.
